name: Avoid using jQuery deprecated methods
description:
Be careful when using deprecated methods. The deprecation period should be used to smoothly make the transition. The rule raises an issue when any of the following methods is used:
- .andSelf()
- .context
- .die()
- .error()
- jQuery.boxModel
- jQuery.browser
- jQuery.sub()
- jQuery.support
- .live()
- .load()
- .selector
- .size()
- .toggle()
- .unload()
output:
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided:
- The number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
rationale: Using deprecated jQuery API could lead to security compliancy issues.
total: Number of JQuery artifacts (Javascript source code containing JQuery)

qualityStandards.name: Use of Obsolete Function
qualityStandards.description: The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

qualityStandards.name: Poor Code Quality
qualityStandards.description: Code quality issues are fairly prevalent within most mobile code. The good news is that most code quality issues are fairly benign and result in bad programming practice. It is typically difficult to detect these types of issues through manual code review. Instead, attackers will use third-party tools that perform static analysis or perform fuzzing. These types of tools will typically identify memory leaks, buffer overflows, and other less severe issues that result in bad programming practice. Hackers with extreme low-level knowledge and expertise are able to effectively exploit these types of issues. The typical primary goal is to execute foreign code within the mobile code's address space.
